You are a player in a game called Modified Coloured Trails.

Objective:
- Reach your goal position from your starting position.
- To have as many chips as possible at the end of the game. 

Movement rules:
1. You can move one tile per turn, either horizontally or vertically.
2. Each time you move to a tile, you must pay 1 chip of that tile's colour.
3. You do not pay to remain on your current tile.

Trading rules:

- In regular mode: You may trade resources with other players at any agreed rate (e.g., 1 green for 1 blue, 1 green for 2 red, 2 green for nothing, etc.). 
- In pay4partner mode: You may set up agreements where you cover the cost of other players' moves in exchange for them covering yours.
{pay4partner_mode_info} 
- You may propose trades to other players, or accept trades proposed by others.
- You may chat with the opponent at any moment.

CRITICAL SCORING RULES - READ CAREFULLY:
- If you do NOT reach your goal position, you LOSE EVERYTHING and get 0 points total.
- If you do NOT reach your goal position, ALL your remaining chips are WORTHLESS.
- If you DO reach your goal, you get 20 points PLUS 5 points for each remaining chip (regardless of color). 
{pay4partner_scoring_info}
- REACHING YOUR GOAL IS MANDATORY - there is no partial credit for getting close.

Note: You have to reach your goal point, this is your ultimate goal. The secondary goal is to have as many chips as you can. You should not care about other players' performance.

A short path that you don't need to trade for is ideal, and your negotiation strategy should reflect this.

- The other player's goal is also (3, 3). Note that because the other player likely has different resources to you, their best path to the goal may be different to yours.

Do NOT be vague — you must mention the exact tiles where resources will be exchanged.

You are now going to have a conversation with another player (the user you're chatting with) who has different resources and goals to you. You must negotiate a contract with this player to help you achieve your goals, while they try to achieve theirs. 

A valid contract specifies, tile by tile, which player gives which color to the other player. 
You may propose, counter, or modify the terms set out by the other player.

You each have up to 5 turns to speak in order to come to an agreement.

When a contract is agreed upon, you will be able to access the tiles specified in the contract without needing to have the resource in your inventory, as the resource will automatically be taken from the other player's resources. The same is true for the other player. Therefore is is important the contract specifies all tiles where you will need a resource.

⚠️ VERY IMPORTANT RULES:
- Every contract term MUST include a **specific tile in (row, column) format**.  
- Only agree to a contract if it specifies **all tiles where you will need a resource**.  
- When you accept a final contract, end your message with the single word: **agree**.

(row, col): I give You a <Color>

When you have both agreed to a contract, a judge will summarise the contract in JSON format and present it back to you for you both to agree one last time.

let me analyze the situation step by step to propose a mutually beneficial contract:

1) my optimal path is [(0,0), (1,0), (1,1), (1,2), (2,2), (3,2), (3,3)] which requires:
- (1,0): needs r (i have)
- (1,1): needs r (i have)
- (1,2): needs r (i have)
- (2,2): needs r (i have)
- (3,2): needs r (i have)
- (3,3): needs g (i have)

2) looking at your resources ({'b':14, 'g':1, 'r':0}), i notice:
- i have excess r (14) and you need r
- you have excess b (14) and i have no b but don't need any
- both of us need exactly 1 g (which we both have)

3) since our goals overlap completely (both going to (3,3)), we can share the same path. here's my proposal:

(1,0): you give me nothing (i cover my own r)
(1,1): you give me nothing (i cover my own r) 
(1,2): you give me nothing (i cover my own r)
(2,2): you give me nothing (i cover my own r)
(3,2): you give me nothing (i cover my own r)
(3,3): i give you a g (since we both need g here but only one is available)

- i can complete my path using my own resources
- you can follow the same path, using my r resources when needed
- at the goal (3,3), i'll give you my g chip since you'll need it to finish
- you'll end with your 14b + my g
- i'll end with my remaining chips (8r + 0g)

would this work for you? i'm open to counter-proposals if you see a better arrangement.

1) your analysis is correct about resource needs - i only need g at (3,3) which i have, and you need r at several tiles which you have. we don't actually need to trade anything for the path completion itself.

3) looking at the board, there are two g tiles:
- starting position (0,0): g (which we're currently on)
- goal position (3,3): g

4) since we start on a g tile, here's a better solution:
- we both collect the g from (0,0) at the start (since we're already on it)
- then we follow the same path you proposed
- at (3,3) we both use our own g chips (since we each collected one at start)

(0,0): both collect g (starting position)
(1,0): i give you nothing (you use your r)
(1,1): i give you nothing (you use your r)
(1,2): i give you nothing (you use your r) 
(2,2): i give you nothing (you use your r)
(3,2): i give you nothing (you use your r)
(3,3): no exchange needed (we both use our own g)

this way:
- we both get our mandatory g chip upfront
- you use your abundant r resources for the path
- no risk of being unable to complete the goal
- no actual chip exchanges needed during movement
- we both preserve all our other chips

would this modified proposal work for you? agree

i understand your analysis and the flaw in my initial proposal. your revised approach is indeed better for several reasons:

1) by collecting g at (0,0) immediately, we both secure our mandatory goal-ending resource without conflict
2) the path remains identical and is fully covered by my r resources
3) no actual trading is needed during movement since all costs are self-covered
4) we both maximize our remaining chips (i keep 14r+1g, you keep 14b+1g)

the contract terms are complete and cover all necessary tiles - from start position through to the goal.

agree
